bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, October 27, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg discusses the favorable reaction to the Cornwell yellow fever painting. He has sent a proof and copies to Agramonte's daughter.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, October 27, 1941
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
October 27, 1941
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am sorry that we were not able to send you more copies of “Del
Diario de Marina”. We did not have it translated. I only had
the article searched to see if there was anything in it about
the painting itself. Our translator said there was nothing be-
yond that they spoke of the painting very highly and at one point
called it “magnificent”, or something to that effect. In other
words, the story was favorable.

I have been away from this office for a full week and have seen a
copy of the reprint from HYGEIA. Aside from some typographical
errors I like the appearance of the reprint very much indeed and
hope you will find it useful. You may look for the insert of
“Conquerors of Yellow Fever” in the November 1st issue of the JOUR-
NAL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSOCIATION. Our distributor from
Cuba was here a couple of weeks ago and saw a proof and told me
that he thought it would produce good feeling among physicians in
Havana. Dr. Marruz has been made director of Public Health since
I, was there and we know definitely that he approves the picture.
In fact, I have a short note from him today. He has not seen the
large print as yet--only the clipping from the New York Sunday
Mirror but a large print is on the way to him.

We shipped the autographed engravers proof which you returned
along with a dozen other framed prints to our distributor in
Havana and they are going to delivery it to Miss Agramonte in
person. I found that to ship one framed print alone was very
expensive and involved a lot of customs difficulties.

Thank you very much for the Dorothy Lynde Dix letter. I did not
want you to go out and purchase this for me but inasmuch as you have
done so I can assure you that it is highly valued.

Our representatives inform us that the doctors here in the United
States are delighted with the “Yellow Fever” painting. The publicity
which the picture had received in newspapers and journals had ar-
roused their interest previous to the time when our prints were pre-
sented by our men and as far as we can tell now this painting is the
most popular produced to date. I was in Boston this past Friday and
our man up there told us he was almost mobbed by doctors in the Leahy
Clinic when he brought up one for one doctor, and that he had had a
similar experience in a large medical building. I think I told you
that we planned to give away 12,000 framed copies but I think the
pressure on us from physicians who will want them will increase that
-2-
number to around 15,000 or even 18,000. Wyeth has the bear by the
tail in this picture venture and won't dare to let go. Fortunately
business is good and the budget is a little more flexible than it
has been in the past.

I hope that you will let me know when you are coming down this way
again as I feel that we should have a self-congratulation party on
this venture.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester
Minnesota
